api_list.name: /points/{point}/forecast/hourly
api_list.description: Hourly forecast data for a point. This response is derrived from the /gridpoints endpoint and is intentionally less structured. If more structure is required, developers should use the /gridpoints endpoint directly. Example: /points/39.0693,-94.6716/forecast/hourly

required_parameters.name: point
required_parameters.description: point: EPSG:4326 latitude, EPSG:4326 longitude

test_endpoint.title: Not Found
test_endpoint.detail: '/points/%7Bpoint%7D/forecast/hourly' is not a valid resource path

api_list.name: /gridpoints/{wfo}/{x},{y}
api_list.description: Raw (commonly referred to as "gridded") data provided by the Weather Office. Every forecast request will use this data to build the forecast response. The grid for a given location is determined by the "property.forecastGridData" property in the /points/{lat},{lon} endpoint. Example: /gridpoints/EAX/40,48

required_parameters.name: wfo
required_parameters.description: wfo: a weather office id (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_National_Weather_Service_Weather_Forecast_Offices)

required_parameters.name: x
required_parameters.description: x: the grid x coordinate

required_parameters.name: y
required_parameters.description: y: the grid y coordinate

api_list.name: /stations/{stationId}/observations
api_list.description: A list of observations for a station.  NOTE! The API uses MADIS to provide observation data. The observation may be delayed while MADIS completes quality checks of the data. To limit the delay, the API is provided with incremental updates with various levels of checked data, and the API will return the variation of the observation with the most checked data. It is possible that no data is provided on the first variation, or that no data is checked on the first variation. It is up to the consumer to determine if the quality of data is appropriate. If not, the previous observation can be requested, or the next nearest station can be used. The API returns the state of the data for each value in the response, where "Z" (or "null") is for not checked (and may never be for some values) and "V" for checked. Please refer to MADIS for complete documentation on their data quality process.  Example: /stations/KMKC/observations

required_parameters.name: stationId
required_parameters.description: stationId: a valid station id (e.g. as provided by the /points/{point}/stations endpoint)

api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://national-weather-service.p.rapidapi.com/products/types"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "national-weather-service.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued June 16 at 3:25PM EDT until June 16 at 4:15PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southeastern Chesterfield County in central Virginia...
The City of Colonial Heights in central Virginia...
The City of Hopewell in south central Virginia...
The City of Petersburg in south central Virginia...
Prince George County in south central Virginia...
Northeastern Sussex County in southeastern Virginia...
Northwestern Surry County in southeastern Virginia...

* Until 415 PM EDT.

* At 324 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Fort
Gregg-Adams, moving southeast at 30 mph.

THIS IS A DESTRUCTIVE STORM FOR PORTIONS OF COLONIAL HEIGHTS,
PETERSBURG, AND PRINCE GEORGE!

HAZARD...80 mph wind gusts and ping pong ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be heavily damaged. Expect
considerable damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles.
Extensive tree damage and power outages are likely.

* This severe thunderstorm will be near...
Disputanta and Garysville around 340 PM EDT.
Burrowsville around 350 PM EDT.
Cabin Point around 400 PM EDT.
Waverly and Claremont around 405 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by this severe thunderstorm include Taylors
Corner, Carsley, Birchett Estate, Spring Grove, Jordan Point Country
Club, Petersburg National Battlefield, Barham, New Bohemia, Richard
Bland College and Prince George Golf.
properties.instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Please report severe weather by calling 757-899-2415, posting to the
NWS Wakefield Facebook page, or using Twitter @NWSWAKEFIELDVA.

CMAMtext: NWS:DESTRUCTIVE WIND STORM in this area til 415 PM EDT. Take shelter now. Check media.
CMAMlongtext: National Weather Service: SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING in effect for this area until 4:15 PM EDT for DESTRUCTIVE 80 mph winds. Take shelter in a sturdy building, away from windows. Flying debris may be deadly to those caught without shelter.

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued June 16 at 3:20PM EDT until June 16 at 3:45PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
properties.description:
At 319 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Mayfield,
moving southeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

Numerous trees have been reported down in Martinsville and southern
Henry county as a result of this storm passing through the area
during the past hour.
properties.instruction:
Prepare immediately for LARGE HAIL AND DAMAGING WINDS, as well as
deadly cloud to ground lightning. For your safety, move to an
interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. Stay away
from windows.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

properties.areaDesc: Lower St. Martin; West Cameron; East Cameron; Upper St. Mary; Lower Vermilion; Lower Iberia; Lower St. Mary; Lower Jefferson
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 16 at 2:18PM CDT until June 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the first Heat Advisory, heat index values up to
109 expected. For the second Heat Advisory, heat index values
up to 114 expected.

* WHERE...In Louisiana, Lower St. Martin and Upper St. Mary
Parishes. In Texas, Lower Jefferson County.

* WHEN...For the first Heat Advisory, from 11 AM this morning to
7 PM CDT this evening. For the second Heat Advisory, from 11
AM to 7 PM CDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat
illnesses to occur.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.areaDesc: Sacramento Foothills and Guadalupe Mountains; Chaves County Plains; Eddy Plains; Lea; Guadalupe Mountains Above 7000 Feet; Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains; Eastern Culberson County
properties.headline: Fire Weather Watch issued June 16 at 2:14PM CDT until June 17 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
properties.description:
* TIMING...Saturday afternoon and evening.

* WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 8 percent.

* RFTI...6 or critical.

* IMPACTS...Avoid the use of open flames or any activities that
may generate sparks. Accidental ignitions will have the
potential to grow quickly into dangerous wind-driven wildfires.
properties.instruction:
A Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions
are forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible

At 311 PM EDT, a large area of wind gusts to near 35 knots covered
parts of Apalachee Bay and the northeast Gulf. These are residual
leftover winds from earlier thunderstorms. The winds will diminish
from west to east through 415 PM EDT. The back edge of the wind
field was located along a line extending from 6 nm south of St.
Marks to 48 nm south of S Tower, moving east at 40 knots.

HAZARD...Wind gusts 34 knots or greater.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect wind gusts in excess of 34 knots...suddenly higher
waves...frequent lightning...and heavy downpours. Make sure
all on board are wearing life jackets.

Locations impacted include...
S Tower, V Tower, Buckeye Reef, Horseshoe Beach, K Tower and Marker
24 Barge.
properties.instruction:
Move to safe harbor immediately as gusty winds and high waves are
expected.

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in BLACKSBURG has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southeastern Buckingham County in central Virginia...

* Until 400 PM EDT.

* At 313 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from near Gold Hill to near Toga, moving southeast at 25
mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Buckingham...
Dillwyn...
Gold Hill...
Sheppards...
Andersonville...
and Toga.
properties.instruction:
Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds, as well as
deadly cloud to ground lightning. For your safety, move to an
interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. Stay away
from windows.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

properties.areaDesc: Humboldt, NV
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 16 at 12:13PM PDT by NWS Elko NV
properties.description:
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Humboldt River At Comus.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 10.5 feet, Moderate Flood Stage. Moderate lowland
flooding throughout the reach, with some rural roads flooded.
Minor flooding in the lower parts of Winnemucca with storm drain
backups. Main area impacted is between the Union Pacific Railroad
and Second street beneath Interstate 80. Property damage in
Winnemucca is minimal.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 11:15 AM PDT Friday the stage was 10.4 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 11:15 AM PDT Friday was 10.6 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 10.4 feet.
- Flood stage is 9.5 feet.
- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of
10.4 feet on 04/03/1993.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Aransas; Coastal San Patricio; Coastal Refugio; Coastal Calhoun; Kleberg Islands; Nueces Islands
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 16 at 2:03PM CDT until June 16 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Corpus Christi TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values from 110 to 114 expected.

* WHERE...Coastal Aransas, Coastal San Patricio, Coastal
Refugio, Coastal Calhoun, Kleberg Islands and Nueces Islands
Counties.

* WHEN...For the first Heat Advisory, until 8 PM CDT this
evening. For the second Heat Advisory, from noon to 8 PM CDT
Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat
illnesses to occur.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.description:
The Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation has issued
a Code Orange Health Advisory for the Clarksville and Nashville areas..
from midnight tonight to midnight CDT Saturday night.

A Code Orange Air Quality Alert for Ozone has been issued. Ground
level Ozone concentrations within the region may approach or exceed
unhealthy standards. The general public is not likely to be
affected. Active children and adults, and people with a respiratory
disease such as Asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion. For
additional information...visit the Tennessee Department of
Environment and Conservation site at
http://www.tennessee.gov/environment.

properties.areaDesc: Buckingham, VA
properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued June 16 at 2:46PM EDT until June 16 at 3:45PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in BLACKSBURG has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northwestern Buckingham County in central Virginia...

* Until 345 PM EDT.

* At 245 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from near Schuyler to near Bent Creek, moving east at 30
mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated. Dime-sized hail observed in Rockbridge
county.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Buckingham...
Wingina...
Toga...
and Centenary.
properties.instruction:
Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds, as well as
deadly cloud to ground lightning. For your safety, move to an
interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. Stay away
from windows.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

properties.areaDesc: Collin; Hunt; Delta; Hopkins; Tarrant; Dallas; Rockwall; Kaufman; Van Zandt; Rains; Hood; Somervell; Johnson; Ellis; Mills; Hamilton; Bosque; Hill
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 16 at 1:29PM CDT until June 17 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values up to 110.

* WHERE...Collin, Hunt, Delta, Hopkins, Hood and Mills Counties.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM CDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity will increase the
risk for heat-related illnesses to occur, particularly for
those working or participating in outdoor activities.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM CDT SATURDAY

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 16 at 1:27PM EDT by NWS Louisville KY
properties.description:
The Louisville Metro Air Pollution Control District and the Indiana
Department of Environmental Management have issued an Air Quality
Alert...in effect from midnight tonight to midnight EDT Saturday
night.

A Code Orange Air Quality Alert for Ozone has been issued for the
Louisville Metro Area.

Members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. The
general public is not likely to be affected. Sensitive groups include
the elderly...children...persons with asthma or other breathing
problems...and persons with lung and heart disease. People in these
groups are advised to limit their outdoor activities to reduce their
exposure to ozone and particulate pollution.

For more information, visit the Louisville Metro Air Pollution
Control District at http://www.louisvilleky.gov/apcd or the Indiana
Department of Environmental Management at http://www.in.gov/idem.

properties.areaDesc: Orange; Washington; Scott; Jefferson; Dubois; Crawford; Perry; Harrison; Floyd; Clark
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 16 at 1:27PM EDT by NWS Louisville KY
properties.description:
The officials at the Indiana Department of Environmental Management
have called for an Ozone action day on Saturday, June 17 for the
following counties...in effect from midnight tonight to midnight EDT
Saturday night.

Dubois
Perry
Orange
Crawford
Washington
Harrison
Scott
Clark
Floyd
Jefferson

Here are some recommended actions that the public can take to reduce
ozone forming emissions:

* Walk, bike, carpool or use public transportation.
* Avoid using the drive-through and combine errands into one trip.
* Avoid refueling your vehicle or using gasoline-powered lawn
equipment until after 7 PM.
* Turn off your engine when idling for more than 30 seconds.
* Conserve energy by turning off lights or setting the air
conditioner to 75 degrees or above.

properties.areaDesc: Imperial Valley
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 16 at 10:21AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
properties.description:
The Imperial County APCD has issued an air quality alert for the
Imperial Valley due to high levels of ozone (smog). The air quality
alert is in effect Saturday, June 17, 2023 from 10 AM until 8 PM.

Elevated levels of ozone  the predominant summertime pollutant
are likely to result in poor air quality in the afternoon and early-
evening hours. Ozone air pollution can cause respiratory health
problems, including trouble breathing, asthma attacks, and lung
damage. Children, older adults, and people with asthma or COPD may
be more sensitive to the health effects of ozone.

Air quality can change depending on time of day and weather
conditions. Increased emissions of chemicals and faster ozone
formation rates due to heat, along with low winds and stagnant
weather can cause unusually high and persistent levels of ozone
pollution.

To help minimize ozone air pollution levels:
Limit the use of gasoline powered lawn and garden equipment until
evening hours
Conserve electricity and set your air conditioner at a higher
temperature
Try to delay trips to the gas station and the use of household
chemicals until the evening

Check air quality levels and take appropriate action as needed. When
air quality index (AQI) levels are Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups
(orange), people with heart or lung disease, pregnant women,
children, and older adults should limit prolonged or heavy outdoor
exertion. When air quality reaches Unhealthy (red) AQI levels,
everyone may experience adverse health effects and sensitive groups
should avoid prolonged time outdoors. At Very Unhealthy (purple) AQI
levels, sensitive groups should avoid all outdoor physical activity
and everyone else should avoid prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion.

To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County
visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at
http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter,
facebook or Instagram (@county_air).

NWSheadline: AIR QUALITY ALERT FOR ELEVATED OZONE AIR POLLUTION

following county, Carroll.

thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream

fallen.

Conway, Fryeburg, Tamworth, Bartlett, Madison, Lovell,
Jackson, Albany, Chatham and Stowe.
properties.instruction:

deaths occur in vehicles.

you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become
killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or
creeks.

properties.areaDesc: Brooks; Inland Kenedy; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Inland Willacy; Inland Cameron; Northern Hidalgo
properties.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 16 at 11:27AM CDT until June 17 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the first Excessive Heat Warning, dangerously hot
conditions with heat index values up to 120 expected. For the
second Excessive Heat Warning, dangerously hot conditions with
heat index values up to 120 expected.

* WHERE...Hidalgo, Brooks, Inland Kenedy, Starr, Inland Willacy,
and Inland Cameron Counties.

* WHEN...For the first Excessive Heat Warning, until 7 PM CDT
this evening. For the second Excessive Heat Warning, from noon
to 7 PM CDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Extreme heat and humidity will significantly increase
the potential for heat related illnesses, particularly for those
working or participating in outdoor activities.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.areaDesc: Sabine; Natchitoches; Winn; Grant; La Salle; Cherokee; Nacogdoches; Shelby; Angelina; San Augustine; Sabine
properties.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 16 at 10:49AM CDT until June 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerously hot conditions with heat index values up to
112.

* WHERE...Portions of north central and northwest Louisiana and
east and northeast Texas.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM CDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Extreme heat and humidity will significantly increase
the potential for heat related illnesses, particularly for those
working or participating in outdoor activities.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM CDT THIS EVENING

properties.instruction:

to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an emergency! Call

properties.areaDesc: Johnson, WY
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 16 at 9:47AM MDT until June 16 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
properties.description:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by several hours of
moderate rainfall continues.

* WHERE...A portion of north central Wyoming, including the
following county, Johnson. This includes creeks and streams around
the city of Buffalo, including Clear Creek and Rock Creek.

* WHEN...Until 600 PM MDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Creek and stream flows are elevated and over their typical banks
in some areas. Ponding of water in urban areas is possible.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 938 AM MDT, emergency management reported that Clear Creek
was out of its banks near and downstream of the confluence
with Rock Creek. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen
over the past 24 hours. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25
to 0.5 inches are expected over the area through 6 pm MDT.
This additional rain may result in additional rises on area
creeks and streams. Rainfall is forecast to end by 6 pm MDT.
- This includes the following streams and drainages...
Sayles Creek, Cummings Creek, Mowry Creek, North Rock Creek,
Negro Creek, South Rock Creek, Pheasant Creek, McVenry Draw,
Boxelder Creek, Shell Creek, Rock Creek, South Fork Shell
Creek, Johnson Creek, Clear Creek, Sand Creek, North Fork
Sayles Creek, North Fork Shell Creek, Healy Draw, Bull Creek,
Dump Draw and North Prong Shell Creek.
- Some locations that may experience flooding include...
Buffalo, Rock Creek, Clear Creek.
properties.instruction:
In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Find an alternate route.

Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement.

NWSheadline: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM MDT THIS EVENING

properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued June 16 at 11:43AM EDT until June 17 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...Walton, Bay, Gulf, and Franklin County Beaches.

* WHEN...Through Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 12:45 PM Friday.
properties.instruction:
Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain
calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

properties.headline: Flood Watch issued June 16 at 9:10AM MDT until June 16 at 11:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be
possible.

* WHERE...Portions of east central Colorado and Kansas, including
the following counties, in east central Colorado, Cheyenne and Kit
Carson. In Kansas, Greeley, Sherman and Wallace.

* WHEN...This afternoon and evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
Low-water crossings may be flooded. Area creeks and streams are
running high and could flood with more heavy rain.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- Slow moving storms are expected to develop along the Colorado
Front Range this afternoon and move eastward into portions of
Eastern-Central Colorado and Northwestern Kansas going into
the evening hours. Heavy rainfall is possible with these
storms which could cause flash flooding to occur.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood
Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared
to take action should flooding develop.

properties.description:
The North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality in Raleigh NC
has upgraded to a Code RED Air Quality Action Day for Fine
Particulates for Brunswick County..until midnight EDT tonight.

The North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality in Raleigh NC
has issued a Code ORANGE Air Quality Action Day for Fine
Particulates for New Hanover and Pender Counties..until midnight EDT

concentrations within the region may approach or exceed unhealthy
standards. For additional information...please visit the North
Carolina Division of Air Quality Web site at

properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued June 16 at 10:30AM EDT until June 16 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Southwest winds 20 to 25 knots, with occasional gusts
30 to 35 knots.

* WHERE...Gulf waters from the Walton-Okaloosa County line to
the Suwannee river out 60 nautical miles.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT /7 PM CDT/ this evening.

* IMPACTS...A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to
33 knots, or seas of 7 feet or greater, are expected to produce
hazardous conditions for small craft. These hazardous conditions
may result in poor vessel handling and steering response,
broaching, overturned dinghies and kayaks, slips and falls on
slippery decks, rub damage along docks and seawalls, and
dragging anchors.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Large clusters of thunderstorms will bring
multiple hours of strong to near gales breezes this morning
through the afternoon.
properties.instruction:
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in hazardous conditions.

properties.areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; North Central; Northwest; Mayaguez and Vicinity
properties.headline: Excessive Heat Watch issued June 16 at 10:23AM AST until June 18 at 5:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.description:
* WHAT...A watch is in effect through Sunday afternoon due to
possible excessive heat index values reaching or exceeding 111
degrees Fahrenheits each afternoon.

* WHERE...For both the watch and warning, the lower elevations
of Puerto Rico from western Puerto Rico and the Culebrinas
River Valley to Levittown.

* WHEN...For the warning, from 10 AM AST to 5 PM. For the watch,
from now through Sunday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...The combination of hot temperatures and high
humidity will create dangerous situations in which heat
related illnesses are likely.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Ample sunshine today will amplify the
effects of the high temperatures.
properties.instruction:
Take extra precautions, if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety
and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest
breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome
by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.   Heat
stroke is an emergency, call 9 1 1.

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 16 at 8:36AM CDT until June 16 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Jackson MS
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values up to 108 expected.

* WHERE...Portions of northeast Louisiana and central, south
central, southwest and west central Mississippi.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM CDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat
illnesses to occur.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Widespread power outages across the area
may further exasperate the affects of the heat and humidity.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.headline: Flood Watch issued June 16 at 6:59AM MDT until June 16 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be
possible.

* WHERE...Wind River Basin, Bighorn Basin, Powder River Basin,
Natrona County, and the surrounding mountains and foothills east
of the Continental Divide in north-central and central Wyoming.

* WHEN...Until 6 PM MDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff from several hours of moderate rain may
result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying
and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of
their banks. Low-water crossings may be flooded. Area creeks and
streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
properties.instruction:
Monitor radar, forecasts, and be alert for possible Flood Warnings
and Advisories. Those living in areas prone to flooding should
monitor streams and creeks and be prepared to take action should
flooding develop.

properties.senderName: NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
properties.headline: Fire Weather Watch issued June 16 at 6:29AM MDT until June 17 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
properties.description:
* WIND...West to southwest at 20 to 25 mph with gusts to 40 mph.

* HUMIDITY... 6 to 14 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
properties.instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.

A Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions
are forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible
Red Flag Warnings.

properties.areaDesc: Absaroka Mountains; Bighorn Mountains West; Bighorn Mountains Southeast; Wind River Mountains East
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 16 at 5:44AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
properties.description:
..Snow likely in the higher elevations of the mountains today...

This is a Special Weather Statement from the National Weather
Service in Riverton...

* WHAT...Snow. Total accumulations of 3 to 6 inches possible
above 10000 feet in elevation.

* WHERE...The Bighorns, Absarokas and Wind River range.

* WHEN...Today, mainly before noon.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Roads over the passes should be mainly wet.
People headed to the higher elevations should prepare for cold
and wet weather.

properties.areaDesc: Coastal waters from Cape Blanco OR to Pt. St. George CA out 10 nm; Waters from Cape Blanco OR to Pt. St. George CA from 10 to 60 nm
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued June 16 at 2:28AM PDT until June 16 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Gale Warning, north winds 25 to 35 kt with
gusts up to 45 kt and very steep seas 10 to 14 ft at 8 seconds
expected. For the Small Craft Advisory, north winds 20 to 30
kt with occasional gusts up to 35 kt and steep seas 6 to 9 ft
at 8 seconds.

* WHERE...Gale Warning tonight into Friday morning south of Port
Orford and mostly beyond 2 NM from shore, except in closer to
shore near the capes. Gales shift south of Cape Sebastian
Friday. Small Craft Advisory north of Port Orford and within 2
NM from shore.

* WHEN...For the Small Craft Advisory, until 11 PM PDT Saturday.
For the Gale Warning, until 11 PM PDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds and steep to very steep seas could
capsize or damage vessels. Low visibility conditions are
expected.

* View the hazard area in detail at https://go.usa.gov/x6hks
properties.instruction:
Mariners should alter plans to avoid strong winds and very steep
seas. Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter course, and/or
secure the vessel for severe conditions.

properties.areaDesc: West Central Mountains; Middle Rio Grande Valley; West Central Basin and Range; Northeast Highlands; Sandia and Manzano Mountains; Central Highlands
properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued June 16 at 3:19AM MDT until June 16 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag
Warning...which is in effect from noon to 9 PM MDT Saturday. The
Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.

* AREA AND TIMING...The Red Flag Warning includes the West Central
Mountains (Zone 105), West Central Basin and Range (Zone 109),
Northeast Highlands (Zone 123), Middle Rio Grande Valley (106),
Sandia and Manzano Mountains (Zone 124), and Central Highlands
(125) Friday afternoon and evening and this includes the same
areas Saturday afternoon and evening.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...West and southwest at 20 to 25 mph with
occasional gusts to 35 mph, except 25 to 35 mph with gusts up
to 45 across the Northeast Highlands (Zone 123) Saturday.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values of 7 to 15 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
properties.instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning and Fire Weather Watch.

Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.

properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...Kenedy Island, Willacy Island and Cameron Island
Counties.

* WHEN...Through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued June 16 at 2:07AM MST until June 16 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Tucson AZ
properties.description:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 151, 152 and 154.

* TIMING...Noon to 7 PM MST today.

* WINDS...Southwest to west at 20 to 25 mph, with gusts 35 to 40
mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...5 to 15 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop or are ongoing will have the
potential to spread rapidly.

* FOR A DETAILED VIEW OF THE HAZARD AREA...Visit
weather.gov/Tucson and click on the Detailed Hazards Icon.
properties.instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now...or are expected to develop. A
combination of strong winds...low relative humidity...and dry
vegetation will create the potential for rapid and erratic fire
growth.

Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of the Red Flag Warning for portions of Southeast Arizona.

* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be
possible.

* WHERE...Portions of panhandle Nebraska and Wyoming, including the

County, Northern Sioux County, Scotts Bluff County and Southern

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- Repeated rounds of rain and thunderstorms may lead to
localized flooding.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

properties.description:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.

* WHERE...Portions of east central Colorado and southeast Colorado,
including the following areas, in east central Colorado, El Paso
County. In southeast Colorado, Pueblo, Crowley, Kiowa, Otero,
Prowers, and Bent Counties.

* WHEN...From Noon MDT today through this evening.

will elevate the risk for flash flooding across portions of

properties.headline: Flood Watch issued June 16 at 2:23AM MDT until June 16 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.

* WHERE...The northern Front Range Foothills, Boulder and Denver
metro areas, Palmer Divide, and adjacent plains through Elbert and
Lincoln Counties.

* WHEN...From Noon MDT today until 10 pm this evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
Extensive street flooding is also possible.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- Numerous showers and thunderstorms will develop this
afternoon and continue into this evening. The stronger storms
will be capable of producing 1 to 2 inches of rain in an hour
or less, and there may be repeated rounds of heavy rainfall.
While the highest threat will be over the Palmer Divide and
in the Cameron Peak burn area, flash flooding will also be
possible in urban locations including the Denver metro area.
properties.instruction:
You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

properties.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 16 at 3:07AM CDT until June 17 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Heat Advisory, heat index values up to 108. For
the Excessive Heat Warning, dangerously hot conditions with
heat index values up to 115 expected.

* WHERE...Portions of south central and southeast Texas.

* WHEN...For the Heat Advisory, until 11 AM CDT this morning.
For the Excessive Heat Warning, from 11 AM this morning to 8
PM CDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Extreme heat and humidity will significantly
increase the potential for heat related illnesses,
particularly for those working or participating in outdoor
activities.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM CDT THIS MORNING... ...EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 8 PM CDT SATURDAY

properties.headline: The Excessive Heat Watch has been replaced. Please see the latest information from NWS San Juan PR on this developing situation.
properties.description: The Excessive Heat Watch has been replaced. Please see the latest information from NWS San Juan PR on this developing situation.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned
room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and
neighbors.

Take extra precautions, if you work or spend time outside.
When possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning
or evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and
heat stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety
and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest
breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome
by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.   Heat
stroke is an emergency, call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM THIS MORNING TO 5 PM AST THIS AFTERNOON

properties.areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; North Central; Northwest; Mayaguez and Vicinity

properties.description: The Excessive Heat Watch has been replaced. Please see the latest information from NWS San Juan PR on this developing situation.
properties.instruction:
Take extra precautions, if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety
and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest
breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome
by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.   Heat
stroke is an emergency, call 9 1 1.

An Excessive Heat Warning means that a prolonged period of
dangerously hot temperatures will occur. The combination of hot
temperatures and high humidity will combine to create a DANGEROUS
SITUATION in which heat illnesses are likely. Drink plenty of
fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and
check up on relatives and neighbors.

Young children and pets should never be left unattended in
vehicles under any circumstances.  This is especially true during
warm or hot weather when car interiors can reach lethal
temperatures in a matter of minutes.

An Excessive Heat Watch means that a prolonged period of hot
temperatures is expected. The combination of hot temperatures and
high humidity will combine to create a DANGEROUS SITUATION in
which heat illnesses are possible. Drink plenty of fluids, stay
in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check up on
relatives and neighbors.

properties.areaDesc: Mobile Coastal; Baldwin Coastal; Escambia Coastal; Santa Rosa Coastal; Okaloosa Coastal
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued June 16 at 1:15AM CDT until June 17 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...In Alabama, Mobile Coastal and Baldwin Coastal
Counties. In Florida, Escambia Coastal, Santa Rosa Coastal and
Okaloosa Coastal Counties.

* WHEN...Through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Choctaw; Washington; Clarke; Wilcox; Monroe; Conecuh; Butler; Crenshaw; Escambia; Covington; Mobile Inland; Baldwin Inland; Mobile Central; Baldwin Central; Mobile Coastal; Baldwin Coastal; Escambia Inland; Escambia Coastal; Santa Rosa Inland; Santa Rosa Coastal; Okaloosa Inland; Okaloosa Coastal; Wayne
properties.headline: Flood Watch issued June 16 at 1:06AM CDT until June 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.

* WHERE...Portions of Alabama, northwest Florida and southeast
Mississippi, including the following areas, in Alabama, Baldwin
Central, Baldwin Coastal, Baldwin Inland, Butler, Choctaw, Clarke,
Conecuh, Covington, Crenshaw, Escambia, Mobile Central, Mobile
Coastal, Mobile Inland, Monroe, Washington and Wilcox. In
northwest Florida, Escambia Coastal, Escambia Inland, Okaloosa
Coastal, Okaloosa Inland, Santa Rosa Coastal and Santa Rosa
Inland. In southeast Mississippi, Wayne.

* WHEN...Through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
properties.instruction:
You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood
Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared
to take action should flooding develop.

NWSheadline: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 16 at 2:04AM EDT until June 16 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Key West FL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values of 106 to 110 expected.

* WHERE...Florida Keys.

* WHEN...Mainly between 12 PM to 4 PM EDT today.

* IMPACTS...A Heat Advisory means that a period of unusually hot
temperatures and high humidity is expected, producing heat
index values of 108 degrees or higher. These conditions will
cause increased risk of heat illness for people outdoors or in
non air conditioned spaces.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible
and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and
Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks
in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by
heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke
is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

properties.areaDesc: Central Beaufort Sea Coast
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 15 at 2:54PM AKDT until June 16 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues.

* WHERE...Sagavanirktok River near Dalton Highway from Mileposts 401
to 407.

* WHEN...Until 600 PM AKDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Flood waters are eroding the Dalton Highway between
Milepost 401 and 407, with the road down to one lane. If
conditions worsen, the road may wash out and become impassible.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 230 PM AKDT Thursday, the Sagavanirktok River continues to
flow overbank due to remnant ice in the main channel. This is
forcing the water to flow west and cause erosion along the
Dalton Highway from Milepost 401 to 407. These conditions are
expected to persist until ice in the main channel clears.
- Rain falling in the headwaters of the Sagavanirktok River
earlier this week is expected move down river through Friday.
This will result in high water levels on the Sagavanirktok
River from near Pump Station 3 to the coast into Friday.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

properties.areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; North Central; Northwest
properties.headline: Excessive Heat Watch issued June 15 at 5:07PM AST until June 18 at 5:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.description:
* WHAT...A watch is in effect through Sunday afternoon due to
possible excessive heat index values reaching or exceeding 111
degrees Fahrenheits each afternoon.

* WHERE...The lower elevations of Puerto Rico from the
Culebrinas River Valley to the greater San Juan and Bayamon
Metropolitan areas.

* WHEN...From now through Sunday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...The combination of hot temperatures and high
humidity will create dangerous situations in which heat
related illnesses are likely.
properties.instruction:
An Excessive Heat Watch means that a prolonged period of hot
temperatures is expected. The combination of hot temperatures and
high humidity will combine to create a DANGEROUS SITUATION in
which heat illnesses are possible. Drink plenty of fluids, stay
in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check up on
relatives and neighbors.

Take extra precautions, if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and
Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks
in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by
heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.   Heat stroke

properties.areaDesc: Mono, CA
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 15 at 1:56PM PDT until June 19 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
properties.description:
* WHAT...Hydrologic flooding caused by snowmelt and warmer
temperatures is expected.

* WHERE...A portion of east central California, including the
following county, Mono.

* WHEN...Until noon PDT Monday. Flows will vary throughout the day
with many creeks and streams seeing the highest flows at night.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Water over mountain roads near creeks and streams. Hazards for
backcountry recreation activities through this weekend in Mono
County.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 135 PM PDT, Gauge reports of several small streams in Mono
county indicated rises and increased flows due to snowmelt.
Warmer temperatures through this weekend will produce further
increases in flows.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Areas near eastern Sierra creeks and streams across Mono
County.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded mountain roads.
Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where
you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can flow over
their banks as snowmelt increases. Campers and hikers should avoid
streams or creeks, which can become dangerous to cross due to fast
and cold flows.

NWSheadline: FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT MONDAY

properties.areaDesc: Osage; Tulsa; Rogers; Creek; Wagoner
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 15 at 3:33PM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
properties.description:
The Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality has issued an ozone
alert for Friday, for the Tulsa metropolitan area.

An ozone alert means that conditions are favorable for the
buildup of ozone near the ground, to an unhealthy level.
When winds are light, the vapors from fuels such as gasoline,
exhaust from engines, and air pollutants from industrial activities
remain trapped near the ground. If sunshine is abundant when these
air pollutants build up, a chemical process is triggered that
results in the development of ozone near the ground during the
afternoon and evening hours.

While ozone in the upper levels of the atmosphere is beneficial in
screening the suns radiation, it is harmful near the ground. Ozone
can bother those with respiratory problems and can damage vegetation.

A few simple measures can be taken to help keep the ozone levels from
becoming unhealthy. During ozone alert days:

Postpone any unnecessary driving and car pool if possible.
If you do drive to work, turn the air conditioner in your car off
during your morning commute. You can also cut down on extra
driving by bringing your lunch to work. If you must refuel your
vehicle, do it in the evening after the sun goes down or postpone
your fueling to another day.

Postpone running the lawn mower and gas trimmer, the exhaust from
these small engines contributes a significant amount of pollution
to the air. Industrial facilities should reduce pollution emissions
as much as possible on ozone alert days.

These preventative measures, performed throughout the Tulsa metro
area, can have a tremendous effect in reducing the pollutants that
contribute to ozone problems.

For further information, contact The Oklahoma Department of
Environmental Quality at (918) 293-1600 or the Indian Nations
Council of Governments /incog/ at (918) 584-7526. Additional
information can also be found at www.ozonealert.com...
including current ozone levels around the Tulsa area.

NWSheadline: OZONE ALERT FRIDAY

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 15 at 3:09PM CDT until June 17 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values 105 to 110 expected.

* WHERE...Portions of north central and northeast Texas.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM CDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity will increase the
risk for heat-related illnesses to occur, particularly for
those working or participating in outdoor activities.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 15 at 3:03PM CDT until June 16 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the first Heat Advisory, temperatures from 103 to
106 are expected. For the second Heat Advisory, temperatures
from 103 to 107 are expected.

* WHERE...Sterling, Coke, Irion, Tom Green, Crockett,
Schleicher, Sutton and Kimble Counties.

* WHEN...For the first Heat Advisory, until 7 PM CDT this
evening. For the second Heat Advisory, from 1 PM to 8 PM CDT
Friday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat
illnesses to occur.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

* WHERE...Florida Keys.

* WHEN...Mainly between 12 PM to 4 PM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...A Heat Advisory means that a period of unusually hot
temperatures and high humidity is expected, producing heat
index values of 108 degrees or higher. These conditions will
cause increased risk of heat illness for people outdoors or in
non air conditioned spaces.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible
and drink plenty of water.

in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by

properties.areaDesc: Leavenworth; Wyandotte; Johnson; Platte; Clay; Jackson
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 15 at 2:26PM CDT by NWS Kansas City/Pleasant Hill MO
properties.description:
The Mid-America Regional Council has issued an Air Quality Alert...in
effect for Friday June 16. Outdoor Air Quality Index, or AQI, values
in excess of 100 are expected with ozone being the primary pollutant.

People and businesses are urged to avoid activities which lead to
ozone formation. These activities include refueling vehicles or
topping off when refueling idling vehicles unnecessarily and using
gasoline powered lawn equipment. Positive activities include car
pooling, biking to work, delaying or combining errands, and using
water-based paints and cleaners.

When pollution levels are elevated, the Mid-America Regional Council
recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor
physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects.
People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated
levels of pollutants include the very young, and those with pre-
existing respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease. Those
with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.

For further information please see the Mid-America Regional Council
air quality program website at http://www.airqkc.org.

NWSheadline: Air Quality Alert in effect for Friday June 16

properties.areaDesc: Wise; Denton; Collin; Hunt; Parker; Tarrant; Dallas; Rockwall; Kaufman; Hood; Johnson; Ellis; Henderson
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 15 at 1:54PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued
an Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Friday,
June 16, 2023.

Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing
high levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area
on Friday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a
ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work,
avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your
vehicle properly tuned.

For more information on ozone:

Ozone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)

Air North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)

EPA Air Now
(www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)

Take care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)

North Central Texas Council of Governments Air Quality
(www.nctcog.org/trans/air/index.asp)

properties.areaDesc: Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast; Northeastern Brooks Range
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 15 at 10:48AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
properties.description:
Rain continues over the northeast Brooks Range east of the Dalton
Highway. Rainfall totals of 1 to 1.5 inches have fallen from
Monday evening through early Wednesday afternoon. Additional
rainfall up to one third of an inch is expected through Thursday
night. Runoff from this rainfall and melting of the remaining
snowpack will cause rivers draining the northeast Brooks Range to
rise to bankfull levels in some locations through Friday. This
includes the Canning, Hulahula, Okpilak and Kongakut Rivers. The
high water will cover gravel bars and cause increased erosion in
some locations. People recreating along these rivers are
encouraged to monitor water levels. Water levels will also rise on
the Sag River, but remain below bankfull.

NWSheadline: High Water Levels Expected This Week

properties.areaDesc: Southeastern Brooks Range; Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 15 at 10:41AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
properties.description:
Around 1 inch of rain fell from Wednesday evening through early
Wednesday afternoon in the southeast Brooks Range. Runoff from
this rainfall and melting of the remaining snowpack will cause
rivers draining the southeast Brooks Range to rise to bankfull
levels in some locations through Friday. This includes the
Chandalar, Sheenjek, Coleen, and Christian Rivers and their
tributaries. Water will cover gravel bars, increased debris will
be coming downriver, and erosion is likely along some riverbanks.

Those living or recreating along rivers draining the southeast
Brooks Range should be prepared for rapid river rises and high
water through this week.

NWSheadline: High Water Levels Into Friday

properties.senderName: NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 15 at 11:23AM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
properties.description:
***LONG DURATION HEAT WAVE LIKELY***

High pressure aloft will build into the area this weekend into
next week and lasting, possibly, until at least the end of the
month. Highs will warm as a result with most lowland locations
expected to reach 95-105, possibly hotter, each day. Additionally,
little relief is expected overnight, especially in urban areas
with lows staying in the 70s. The hottest areas will be along the
Rio Grande Valley, especially across Southern Dona Ana County into
Texas. El Paso will see lows stay in the mid to upper 70s.

The cumulative effect of heat with little overnight relief will
compound the risk for heat-related illness. It is important to
stay hydrated. Avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol consumption.
If possible, shift outdoor activities toward the morning or later
in the evening. Wear light colored, loose fitting clothing. Use
sunscreen.

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 15 at 11:53AM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
properties.description:
The Iowa Department of Natural Resources has issued an Air Quality
Advisory for portions of central and eastern Iowa.

Fine particulate levels near or above EPA health standards are
expected to increase throughout the day and persist in these areas
through Friday. Elevated levels of fine particulates may be a
concern over the next several days as the smoke moves through the
state.

The DNR recommends that people reduce long or intense activities,
and take more breaks during outdoor activities until air quality
conditions improve. The recommendation is especially pertinent to
individuals with heart or lung disease, older adults, children and
teenagers, and outdoor workers. People in these categories should
consider rescheduling or moving outdoor activities indoor.

properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued June 15 at 4:33AM CDT until June 17 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...In Alabama, Mobile Coastal and Baldwin Coastal
Counties. In Florida, Escambia Coastal, Santa Rosa Coastal and
Okaloosa Coastal Counties.

* WHEN...Through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.areaDesc: Rains
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 15 at 3:31AM CDT until June 16 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values 105 to 110 expected.

* WHERE...Rains County.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM CDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity will increase the
risk for heat-related illnesses to occur, particularly for those
working or participating in outdoor activities.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.headline: Flood Watch issued June 14 at 4:49PM CDT until June 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flash Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.

* WHERE...Portions of southeast Alabama, Panhandle Florida and
Georgia, including the following areas, in southeast Alabama,
Coffee, Dale, Geneva, Henry and Houston. In Panhandle Florida,
Holmes, Jackson and North Walton. In Georgia, Baker, Ben Hill,
Berrien, Brooks, Calhoun, Clay, Colquitt, Cook, Decatur,
Dougherty, Early, Grady, Irwin, Lanier, Lee, Lowndes, Miller,
Mitchell, Quitman, Randolph, Seminole, Terrell, Thomas, Tift,
Turner and Worth.

* WHEN...Through Friday evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water
crossings may be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- Several inches of rainfall has already fallen in the past two
days over the watch area. Additional rainfall of 3 to 6
inches with locally higher amounts is forecast from today
through Friday.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood
Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared
to take action should flooding develop.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 13 at 10:17PM MDT until June 16 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...South Platte River near Balzac.

* WHEN...From late tonight to late Friday evening.

* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, There is extensive flooding of
agricultural land near the river. Water flows over State Highway
63 near Atwood.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...

- At 9:30 PM MDT Tuesday the stage was 8.3 feet.

- Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage just after
midnight tonight to 10.7 feet Wednesday morning. It will then
fall below flood stage Thursday night or Friday.

- Flood stage is 10.0 feet.

- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of
10.4 feet on 06/12/1995.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 12 at 9:20AM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
properties.description:
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...James River At Ashton.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Water reaches the bottom of the bridge 3
miles north and 1 1/2 mile east of Ashton

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:45 AM CDT Monday the stage was 14.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:45 AM CDT Monday was 14.1 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 13.5 feet Monday
morning.
- Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
